text: Bottle with PatrickFannon 5-6 years ago. Pours hazy yellow golden with a smaller sized head and average lacing. Aroma of flowers, apples, chamomile, lemon skin, pears, grapes and some toasty malts. Medium bodied with a dry close. Awesome beer.

My first review can only be for the beer that started it all for me eight years ago at Spuyten, and which I always go back to (if/when I can find it, which is extremely rare in DK). This beer is wild ale perfected, vinous, clean, with a fruity sourness. Could drink this for ages. Even after meeting Cantillon Ive never stopped yearning for this one.
Bottled. Wonderful aroma, a lot of fruits with a taste of gueuze. Quite amazing.
Fast klare goldene Farbe, geringe weiße schaumkrone. Geruch minimal säuerlich, mild fruchtig, hefig. Geschmack nach Ananas, helle Früchte, mild.
Heller, trocken und mild säuerlicher Antrunk. Leicht steigende Säure, minimal herb, vollmundig. Trockener heller Nachhall, spritzig. 10/9/9/9/6/9

Bottle thanks to fishmich! Pours cloudy apricot, medium creamy off-white head, dissipates slowly, nice lacing. Aroma is Brett funk, sweat socks, basements, oak, stonefruits. Flavor is light plus tart, light funk, lemon and lime, Brett and oak. Medium body, Very tasty.

From bottle into a snifter. Nice very cloudy gold color with medium sized white head with fine bubbles. Nose has nice sour notes, lemon, barnyard, some biscuit malts, maybe some corn, . High carbonation, medium sweetness, moderate sour, hints of funk, slightly dry finish with some more sour, very well balanced. This is a very well crafted beer, very complex, smooth, drinkable, blew me away.
Pours a pale gold with a white head. Aroma is citrusy and spicy. Tastes tart and spicy with some bready malt, wood, and sweetness. Medium body.
Blonde doré. Entré surette. Fruité. Baies. Belle amertume. Légèrement boisé. Mûre (Piquante). Melon. Citronné. Levure sauvage. Excellente.
это пиво очень вкусно. я бы, конечно, рекомен& его всем. пожалуй& обратит& его. очень хорошо!
Bottle from Lawson. Batch 1, 2013. Pours a bright, tawny golden orange, some bit of head. Aroma citrusy, Brett, juicy, body lively and tart, finish dry and lovely. This is top notch.
Bottle - Tart, citrus, white grape and a nice sweetness. Clear gold with a thin white head. Effervescent and well carbonated. Lots of tartness and white grape. Easy drinking and quite nice.

750ml bottle, shared with the staff at Dutchs. Mostly clear golden orange color, with lots of very-fine particles suspended in the body. Thin ring of off-white head, leaving good ropes and dots of lace. Satisfyingly oaky flavor, lemon-citrus and acidity, some mild belgian-type yeast, light spiciness, and good bigger farmhouse barnyard funky flavors. Medium body. Smooth, kind of crisp, lighter carbonation. Lightly slick in the mouthfeel. Satisfyingly moderate sour taste, lighter to moderate sweet. Wonderful big oaky and lightly citric flavor. Great, sour golden ale. Not really like any biere de garde Ive ever had -- lacks that big, soft, highly carbonated spicy mouthfeel that is common with the style, but I dont miss that aspect at all. Do get the a lot of oaky funkiness and mild spiciness that is reminiscent of traditional examples, though. Just like Jolly Pumpkin is known to do, this example of biere de garde takes a lot of liberties... with pleasing results.

Bottle @ home, thanks to readbaron. This beer rocks! Hazy golden orange appearance with a thin white head. The carbonation is a bit dull but this is an otherwise great beer. Theres a massive amount of bubblegum, pineapple / tropical fruit brett, and candy in the nose. Some moderate acidity - both lactic and acetic. Some cheese, lots of tropical fruit, mango, passion fruit, and pineapple. Theres vanilla and oak in there as well. Moderately tart. Tons of candy. Low bitterness and sweetness. If the carbonation was higher, this would be a 4.5-4.6. Supremely chuggable. JesusOfCO- this is what you should be aiming for. Fuck yeah.

Bottle, batch 1 2013, nearly two years old. Pours a clear yellow-gold with small white head that quickly subsides. Aroma is pleasantly gueuze-like, though much less tropical than I remember it being the first time I had this beer (and didnt rate it). White wine, lemons, musty cork, and lots of stone fruit, like unripe peach. Taste is moderately sour and acetic with lemon juice, oak tannins, unripe peach, light honey, and green mango. Im reminded slightly of Temptation. Aroma is really the star here but its an excellent beer overall, even if it lacks the magical tropical fruit of bottles past.

@ Party Source / Bellevue KY --- Cloudy light amber with a nice bubbly white head that drops quickly to a cover, streaks and shreds of lace. Taste is tart sour lemon and wheat and hay that is excellent as a quencher and appetite awakener. When does bier de garde become sour ale? This one must be close to the edge. Still, it is well done.

Batch 1 2013. Purchased in westlake, OH. Off comes the cap and out comes the beer! Pours a beautiful golden with an inch of white head and a whisp of lacing. Both disappear rapidly. Funky farmhouse aroma. Mouthfeel is light with a good dose of carb. Taste is tart! I wasn't expecting a sour beer. Flavors include lemon farmhouse must sawdust etc. great flavors and a fantastic beer. I am very impressed. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Devil Den, Philadelphia 750ml bottle: Pours golden with a white head. Aroma is bretty funk, tart fruit, and sour ale aroma. Taste is way more similar to a sour ale than to a biere de garde. In fact, I dont think I have ever had a biere de garde this sour. But, it is a nice, slightly lemony sourness. Very mild amount of sweetness. Nice tart finish. Quite good.
bottle. Golden with one finger head. Holy smokes this is sour. I cant imagine that drinking straight lemon juice would be any more tart. I love sours, but this might be over my limit.
Refrigerated 75 cl brown bottle poured into a tulip. Aroma is slightly tart, light body, some lacing, and low carbonation. Taste is tart and some oak.

750 ml bottle. Pours a a lighter yellow with a thin white head. Not much retention. Aroma is fairly juicy and sour with a tartness similar to the part of a plum just beneath the skin. Tastes pretty tart and dries out in the finish.

3/29/13. 750mL shared by GT2 at Meridian Pint during CBC. Golden pour with a small off-white head. Lots of stone fruits and tropical fruits with some lactic and acidic tartness. Juicy, fruity, and lightly tart all around. Really good stuff and I wish they would have let us buy the other Leelanau bottles to try as well.
Bottle. Very good sour. Nice color. Complex flavor...very tart but still pleasant. Very clean finish.
Bomber. Hazy gold. Tart, funk and yeast. Super tart and clean. Goes down easy.

Bottle from Capones.  Pours turbid bright, deep gold with off-white head and a lot of carbonation.  Nose is funky yeasty malt, hopcitrus, notes of florals.  Tastes complex, semi-dry with hopcitrus, a pronounced tartness, and funky yeast esters.  Finishes complex.

Bottle. Thanks to Jay for picking this up for me. Pours clear gold with white head. Nose and taste of Brett, lemon funk, canned peaches, citrus and orange zest, tart pear, light bread and oak. Medium body.
Bottle shared by a friend. Cloudy yellow pour with a medium white head. Aroma of malt, orange, lemon and funk. Malty and wheaty flavor with some oak character before a citrusy and sour finish.

Sample at the Aficionados "Hidden Gems" beer tasting on 05/24/2013: Pours a hazy golden color with a medium thick off-white head that diminishes slowly. Small patches of lacing on the glass. Aroma of citrus, oak and malt. Medium-bodied with flavors of bretty oak, apricot and biscuit malt. The finish is fruity with an oaky and herbal aftertaste. Pretty good all around.

Bottle. Hazy gold pour with a small ring of white foam. Grainy lemony aroma, pretty typical american sour farmhouse ale, tart flavor, citric acidity light bodied and refreshing. Palate is dry, with lively carbonation.

Bottle 750ml.
Pours blond/golden with low white head. Some lacing. Aroma is of fruits, sourness. Taste is pretty much the same. Palate: Ligth body. Overall: Very fruity, somewhat ligth body. A good beer.

Bottle (750 ml). Shared by Julien, Pier-Luc & Benoit, thanks! Pours cloudy straw color with a small white head and some lacing. Aroma is fruity (peach, lemon, apricot, pear) with wood/oak, tart and funky notes. Taste is slightly sweet and moderately sour with, again, lots of fruits (peach, lemon), wood, funky notes and an underlying malt presence. Light to medium body. Moderate carbonation. Very good refreshing Sour (Bière de Garde?), but theres something missing to make it a great beer.

Bottle from Pier-luc and Julien, Thanks! Pours a cloudy blond, small white head, little lacing. Aroma is fruity, peaches,lemony, oak. Taste is fruity, peaches, lemon, a bit herbal, funk, tart, oak. Low body and medium carbonation. Pretty good stuff.

750mL shared at Meridian Pint during CBC celebrating my 5500th rating. Pours a glowing, low haze peach color with minimal acid cut foam. Nose is brilliant peach/nectarine, juicy, fresh, like smelling fresh fuzzy peach juice after a bite. Taste is bright starfruit, peach/nectarine, and Im told crabapple. Palate is perfectly lactic sour. Bright, fresh, brilliant nectar fruit flavor all around. Incredible.

From the bottle at Meridian Pint.  Pours a slightly-hazy light peach color. Nose is light funk, wheat, and heavy stone fruit. Reminiscent of fruity batches of Fantôme Saison. Fruity and tart with a bit of body.  Really exceptional and super smooth for 7.5%.  An amazing beer that I was absolutely stunned by.

750 ml bottle into tulip glass, bottled on 4/29/2011.  Fast gusher upon opening as expected, but didnt lose any.  Pours very cloudy golden straw color with a 2 finger dense and fluffy bright white head with great retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers.  Nice spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass, with plenty of carbonation streaming off the sediment.  Aromas of huge tart lemon, peach, sour apple, pear, apricot, pineapple, pepper, clove, oak, hay, straw, funk, and earthy spiciness.  Incredible aromas with great balance and complexity of fruity, spicy, and funk notes.  Taste of big peach, tart lemon, sour apple, pineapple, pear, apricot, clove, pepper, hay, straw, oak, funk, light leather, and earthy spiciness.  Moderate tart acidity on the finish; with lingering notes of tart lemon, peach, pear, sour apple, pineapple, apricot, clove, pepper, hay, straw, oak, light leather, and earthy spiciness on the finish for a while.  Fantastic complexity and balance of tart fruity, spicy, and funk flavors; with nearly zero cloying flavors present after the finish.  Medium-high carbonation and medium bodied; with a crisp, acidic, and lightly prickly mouthfeel that is very nice.  Alcohol is very well hidden with only a slight warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is an absolutely incredible barrel aged wild golden ale.  Huge complexity and balance of tart fruity, spicy, and funk notes; and very smooth to sip on.  A highly fantastic offering.  As the carbonation died out because of the gusher, it became slightly harder to drink; but with full carbonation this was absolutely insane.

great beer. tons of sea-foam cream head. rocky head and sticky lacing.  nose is full of tart green apple, oak, and slight earthy essence. taste follows nose with a fair amount of directness. good carbonation, medium mouthfeel with slight oily residue and dry, oaky finish.
Hazy golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, fruity, citrus, yeasty and brett. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate acidic. Dry and moderate finish. 300912

Bottle, 7.5%. Slightly hazy golden with small white head. Aroma is malt, fruit, hops, grapefruit and brett. Flavour is malt, brett, fruit, little dry, little sweet, oak, little sour, little grapefruit and medium bitter.
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are rich fruits, brett, malt, citrus, wood and hops.

Aroma complex que evoluciona continuament. Notes àcides en boca i de cert envelliment en bóta. Al cul hi queden notes més amarges dibuprofè i el color és més tèrbol. Em sembla més una saison que una biere de garde.ot i això seria molt interessant envellir una botella i provar-la 10 anys més tard a veure com ha evolucionat. Gran.

(Bottle) Pours light hazy pale golden with an off-white head. The aroma holds citrus/lemon, lemongrass,  grapes, green apples, roses, tulips, lavender, herbs, tart apricots, white bread, light dough, wet grain, dry crackers, old wood, marzipan, old wood, damp basement, touch phenols and whisper of horse. Maybe a hint of red berries. The aroma is light sweet to dry, medium acidic and light to no bitterness with notes of citrus, tart fruits, grapes/white wine, pale malt, some yeast, herbs light farmhouse, as well as a touch of herbs and flowers. The mouthfeel is tart with a light carbonation. Lacto and citrus finish. Near medium bodied.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2012 750 ml bottle courtesy of Marsiblursi. Pours hazy pale golden with a rather small creamy white head that slowly dissipates while leaving lots of stick trace and some lacing on the glass. Smell is tiny sweet, tiny sour and funky with crackers, lemon juice, hay, green grapes, lemon zest, peaches, brett, dry soil, barnyard, apricots, orange zest, alcohol and hints of  rubber and cereal. Taste is tiny sweet and sour with lemon juice, crackers, lemon zest, hay, lemon grass, dry soil, dusty barnyard, dark grapes, leather, apricots, peaches, pineapple, passionfruit and hints of cloves, white pepper and dry wood. Mouthfeel is round, slightly dry, slightly tart and medium bodied. Finish is sour and tart with crackers, dry wood, green grapes, lemon juice, hay, dry dusty barnyard, lemon zest, passion fruit and dried apricots. World class beer!
Great stuff here even though its very expensive.  Aroma is citrus and funk with pale malts and spice.  Taste is mildly tart and lightly spicy and funky.  Loved it.
Bottle. Smooth like a wheat beer, with a moderate refreshing sourness. Not too barnyardy. Crisp.

750ml bottle shared by FatPhil and Anna. I love the color, looks golden like liquid honey. Very nice. Little head. Pineapple in aroma. As well in taste. This is first time I drink this kind of beer so its very sour for me. I can actually feel how the acid goes through my system, dissolving everything in its path. Yeast smoothers the taste.
Mmmmmm... Mmmmmm... Thats what  this beer makes you do. The Brett is folded into the malt and yeast elements beautifully.

750ml bottle (BierKompass.de) - shared with Marduk - thanks!
Came on my hand after popping the cap. Nothing measurable lost though. Lovely honey look, a touch cloudy, and a few of sinky bits. Slightly pineapply aroma, but a nice lambickiness too, touch of apricot. Body much more apricotty. Certainly reminiscent of Cantillons bretty body, but this is quite a lot stronger. Theres a fair bit of grapefruit and citrus in the retronasals, and alas theres some wafting of alcohol that comes across with that. Not never as booze, simply as a vapourousness. Yeast and crap are something you dont want to worry about, this is lovely and crisp without additional crap, and is pleasantly mellowed by adding it all. I prefer the bite.

Bottle 750 ml 2011 Bottle  
 Aroma:   green apple , horse blanket, gooseberry, fruity sweet hints behind.7+
 Appearance:   slight haze, amber-gold. Frothy mid top. 3+.
 Palate / Taste:  Medium bodied. Dry front, plenty of what appears to be cinnamon like notes, mellow apple with spices, some tartness. Interesting approach to style. Less malty and more sour funk than most.

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2013 Old Rating: Shared from bottle. Poured a slightly hazy yellow color with a small white head. Aroma was very light fruit notes, a touch of a tart and spicy character to it. Flavor was enjoyable, but just not exactly my cup of tea. Liked the slight sour notes to it over everything else.Update: Had this again thanks to GT! Aroma was fruit notes, sour, acid. Very tart and good.

750ml green bottle.

It pours a slightly hazy old with a fizzy bright white head that dissipates rather quickly with no lacing.

The smell is really sour, I was surprised. It has a tingly passionfruit nectar scent along with some sour green apple, tangerine, lemon, and pineapple. There are some sweet malts in the background accentuating the tropical nature. There is some flowery/herbal scents going on too. There is a slight funk but not too much, more of just a slightly funkier saison yeast.

The flavor is interesting. It is nicely sour with sour green apple peel, lemon zest, and acid. There is a bit more funkiness going on with a long funky aftertaste. There is a tiny bit of hops and oak. This one is mostly sour.

A great surprise, something I have passed over a lot but glad I got to try.
En botella.color dorado palida,bien balanceada,con aromas a manzana verde,sin llegar a ser demasiado acida.

Notes florals i cítriques en laroma, que és molt potent, es pot sentir laroma a una certa distància. Sembla més una Ale Sour que una Biere Garde. Bastant seca amb una acidés molt suau. Tosc de poma verda. Bon cos i bona sensació en boca.

This beer is courtesy of mystikyle, thanks Kyle!

It pours a light bodied very cloudy, almost Belgian wit gold in color with a soapy one finger head. The nose is phenomenal. It is slightly tart with a white orchard fruit type subtle sweetness. There is just a soft touch of butter. The flavors are both sweet and tart. It has some pear and white apple characteristics and finishes with a good amount of brett. Its just a really well balanced sour. It drinks a about medium in body with adequate carbonation. Overall this is a really nice and easy drinking sour. I love the fruit characteristics with the right amount of tartness. This is a really nice beer.

From notes.  First reviewed 7/5/2011.  Poured from a 750 mL bottle into a tulip. Thanks to Dunt for bringing out this bottle and introducing me to another fun Michigan brewery.

Out of the bottle this pours a relaxed yellow, cloudy, with a soft off-white cap. Just a few gentle spots of lace remain down the glass.

The aroma is full of fun bugs. Very tart, vinegar, lemon rind, some apricot, and a little funk.

The flavor is nice and sour. The flavor starts and stays sour the whole time, with a lot of lemon, some apricot, and some grassy notes playing in the forefront preventing the Brett from wreaking havoc on my palate. Some spicy notes and a little oak add some depth. 

The body is definitely on the light side, with medium carbonation. The tartness creates a nice puckering sensation without being over the top. Overall I find the feel works well with the flavors.

This is an enjoyable brew and I would be interested to try their other offerings. This is big enough to keep me interested, but light enough to be refreshing in the summer.

0.75 l bottle. Hazy yellow color, a gusher. Fruity, perfumed and spicy aroma with strawberry, clove and cheese. Dry tart taste with citrus, grapefruit, pepper, pineapple and cheese. Wheaty mouthfeel. Nice tropical taste, quite artisanal.

[4288-20120209] Bottle. Deliciously fresh fragrant pear flower yeast aroma with hints of spice in the background. Hazy, light orange brown body with a quick foamy white head. Fresh yeasty apple pineapple flower flavour. Medium body. Delicious, quite refreshing and simple. (9/3/7/3/15) 3.7
(@ Volo, Toronto, ON)

2012-02-09.  Hazy golden orange body, small white head. 3+ Odd aroma at first, sort of earthy must mix of vegetation, muted orange touches, mild funk. 6+ Flavour starts a bit muddled, funky musty character, mild acidity grows slowly, mild oaky accents grow as well, lemon notes, very light earthy bits. Lovely highlights but the overall impression is less than the sum of its parts. Average to light bodied palate, soft carbonation. Bottle at Volo, Toronto
Golden colour. Whihe head. Honey, peachy, floral, and sour aroma. Sour, peach, tangerine and banana flavour. A Gueze-fruit beer-IPA hybrid. Awesome stuff.

75 cl bottle, bottled 29.04.2011
Aroma is tart with citron and earthy notes. Actually very typical to JP ales. Flavour is rather tart with citron and some orange. Less salty than JP stuff usually is. Some hints of alcohol can be observed at the end of the glass. Good, but the tart citron is too intensive for me. Adding the yeast rounds the taste, but the citron is still there.

Dark yellow colored with hazy appearance, little yellow head. Strongly yeasty, even bit skunky aroma with rich lemon, sourness and some sweet vanilla. Medium bodied. Flavor is also sweet-sour with lemon and grass, aftertaste lasts with sour touch.

75 cl bottle @ Timo A. Bottled 29.04.2011.
Pours hazy golden colour with small head. Aroma of citrus, spices, herbs, apricot, mild peach and grass. Flavour of sour citrus, apricot, herbal notes, spices and yeast, some barnyard notes also. Nice and sour palate. Very good.
4355

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2012 Bottle. Not cheap at about $18/bottle. Pours a slightly hazed light golden color with a slight white head. Some lacing. Nice nose, lemon zest and some caramel. Medium/light mouthfeel. Lemon and pineapple off the bat. Some oaky notes in the back end. lingering Chardonnay like flavor. Decent but not sure if it is worth the cost.

Bottle from La Cervecería in the East Village, courtesy of the owner (got his name but cant remember it now - oh well). Pours a bright yellow-orange with good hue. Smells great: citrus, zest, vinegar, tartness. Palate has all of the above with an almost perfect level of acidity. Shared this with the whole table and everyone enjoyed it. Great example of what I like about sours, even if it isnt technically classified as such: airy vinegar and fruit on the nose, tart fruit flavors, acidic mouthfeel and a mouth-watering "puckeriness" to the whole thing. Great sipping. Many thanks to La Cervecería.
Green apple peel and lemon in the aroma.  Flavor is more tart than the other Leelanaus Ive had and fairly complex with the oak showing through along with the classic JP house funk.

Bottle. Golden, cloudy, small and fully diminishing head. Moderate malty - lightly wheaty and dryish aroma with some sourness, citrus fruitiness and faint spiciness (pepper), light hoppyness. Body is medium, malty - lightly wheaty and dryish flavor, light fruitiness with citrus and light sourness, faint spiciness, light hoppyness with faint vanilla - oak. Finish is average to long, malty - lightly wheaty and dry, citrus and some fruitiness, light spiciness with some hoppyness, faint vanilla. Nice dryish fruity ale with citrus aroma - faint oak.

750ml bottle from Bierkompass

Pours light orange with a small white head. Aroma has notes of fruits, earthy notes, pumpkin, peach, spices and malts. Taste is quite fruity with earthy notes and malts. Finish is slightly sour and bitter with notes of fruits. Okay, quite well balanced ale.

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2012 750 ml bottle.
Pours a hazy bright yellow colour with a white head. Aroma of pumpkin and sweet fruits. Flavour of pale malts, pumpkin, sweet fruits, wood, spices and some yeast. Some sour Jolly Pumpkin house flavour notes too. Medium bodied, slick mouthfeel and a finish of sour sweet fruits and some spices. Enjoyable.
750 ml bottle.
Pours a golden colour with a white, somewhat lacy head. Aroma of strong citrus and sweet fruits. Flavour of pale malts, citrus, strong wood and of course Jolly Pumpkin like sourness, which reminds me of a light gueuze. Medium bodied, slick mouthfeel and a lovely sour, somewhat fruity finish. No pumpkin in this bottle.

Tepid peach color, large bubbles with no head. Nose is peach, wheaty, very dirty for JP, not quite as dusty, bit thinner and less bretty. Flavor is bit more citric, punchy, wheat with tartness in the finish, lightly puckering, Overall quite watery, disappointingly low carbonation, thin, lightly oily, hot, almost a wheaty unblended lambic, definitely my least favorite of this line, saved by how sweat the peach is here.

Bottle: &nbsp Deep hazy straw, moderate sudsy white head, spotty lacing. &nbsp Floral and citrus notes on the 

nose. &nbsp I am also getting some assertive wood character showing up in this one. &nbsp Very strong aroma, can smell 

this beer a few feet away. &nbsp Seems to have more in common with a Sour Ale than a Biere de Garde. &nbsp Strong 

woody character up front, sharp floralness, very soft candied citrus peel. &nbsp Fairly dry, a tart beer bordering on 

sour. &nbsp Fairly tasty, and unique albeit the Biere de Garde portion seems to fall by the wayside. &nbsp This really 

could double as a Sour Ale. &nbsp Full to moderate on both the body and mouthfeel. &nbsp Clean finish, dry but not 

super dry. &nbsp This one also has a unripened apricot skin like flavor. &nbsp This one was sort of an unexpected 

surprise. &nbsp Thanks to pailhead for this treat!

Bottle at FoBAB 9. Pours a lightly hazed gold with a fluffy white head. The nose is distinctly JP funk, though lighter. Soft vanilla notes and a nice maltiness to the nose as well. On tasting, light tartness and farmyard. Bit of oak and a rounded ester profile that works nicely. Wouldnt call this a BdG (even though they do), but its a nice beer overall.

Tasted some time in mid-2011 from a 750mL bottle purchased at Lush West Town, bottled on 8/12/10.  This bottle was a bit of a gusher.  Pours hazy yellow with a thick white head recedes quickly to a thin white collar of lace.  The nose has the signature Jolly Pumpkin sour funk, along with lemon pith, a hint of lactic creaminess, and some light cereal and hay malts.  The flavor is the same, starting with the light malts, and moving on to lemon pith, a lactic note, and finishing with the funky barnyard.  The body is medium and oily, with light carbonation, and a long sour lemon, vanilla oak, and tannic finish.

On tap during MBF2010, RBSG. Wild fermentation im told. Dude, this smells outrageous! (yelled at the guy serving the beer). This is a ridiculous beer. French oak aged! Hazy gold stuff with a white skull, great aroma. Fruit and very oaky, sour , lemon, orange, maybe melon? little bit sweet candy, funy throughout, smooth and airy - wonderful. Tastewise: great funk and damn sour, lemony, ends with a light spice that peels off into a light nectarine finish which is quite a surprise, acidic, more funk on the finish... even more.. finishes powerful. Hell of a beer!

Bottle. 24.5 oz. Split with and courtesy of Vinnie. Pours an opaque glowing yellow with a fat off-white head thay fades to leave a spotty sudsy surface. Aroma of yellow apples, Belgian spices, lemon zest, salty mildew, tart pears, some corny pilsner malts. Medium bodied with a zesty, juicy, spicy-sweet mouthfeel; plently of dryness and floral resins to balanace out the tangy, oaky flavors. Finishes with an estery, slighty hoppy flourish. Excllent ale.

Ahhh that beautifully bright, delicate, and delicious mouthfeel that every JollyPumpkin has branded in its DNA.  Reminds me of the moment when I had Calabaza for the first time.  Golden yellowish body with nice white lacing.  Slighty tart yeasty with lemon zest and peaches.  By far my favorite BdG.. but really has its own style.. Jolly Pumpkin.

Bottle split with streets, Andrew, and Brendan.  Pours a bright hazy golden yellowish body with nice white lacing. Aroma is fruity nose, tarty yeast and lemon zest. Mouthfeel is smooth with notes of sour yeast, lemon zest, sour peach skins. Great beer!

Slightly hazy golden coloured body with a very thin whtie head and almost no movement at all. Light of citrus, honey, sour grapes, sour cherries, oak, viognier, apricots and a little touch of coriander seed. Light to Medium-bodied; Sharp oaky and pungent malt flavour with a lot of citrus, lemons, light spices and a touch of the honey and honeysuckle. Aftertaste is quite complex with a touch of barnyard notes, yeast and some floral notes. Overall, a good and complex beer, but lacking in strong flavours, carbonation and some other notes - but a good beer, just not amazing and not necessarily a biere de garde. I sampled this 75 cL bottle purchased at Merchants in Dearborn, Michigan two days earlier on 28-April-2011 for US$16.99! sampled at a friends house in Northville, Michigan on 30-April-2011.

It pours a golden straw color, not unlike any macro brewed swill, at least until the yeast arrives. Appearances, however, are the last thing standard about this brew. It opens very fruity with a pronounced tart finish. The malty sweetness blends with hints of vanilla and an estery sweet-tart carbonation as it rolls around the tongue. The tartness can be a bit much alone, but it pairs nicely with many dishes or cheeses and its lighter body belies the supposed 7.5 percent ABV and 1067 original gravity, according to the brewers notes. While it certainly doesnt seem that strong, it is very complex. I found hints of tannins, citrus lemon, and pineapple over the course of the bottle. 

That all said, this ale is probably not for everyone. The tartness can be offsetting and its complexity is pretty standard for most Belgian yeast strains. As a biére de garde ("beer for keeping"), Im also not sure how the lighter body will hold up if this beer is aged--per the label suggestion--up to a decade ...although, I have a feeling it will do nothing but sour for the worse.

Its a nice brew, very interesting, but nothing extraordinary.

Serving type: bottle

750 ml bottle.  Pours a hazy pale golden color with a small white head.  The aroma is lightly tart with peach, apple cider and bready malts.  The flavor is tart and fairly dry with lemon citrus, lactic acid, pineapple and a doughy bread.  Medium bodied with moderate carbonation.
750 ml bottle.  Citrus fruit on the nose. Somewhat tart somewhat sweet.  Pours a cloudy gold.  Tart citrus, kumqats, a little sweetness with tart citrus fruit finishes somewhat dry.  Good.

750mL bottle.  Poured hazy medium golden with a shortish cap of white head and plenty of rising bubbles.  The aroma picked up sour oak and lemony notes first and foremost, accented by some funky, footy yeast.. a touch leathery.. smelled like it was going to be very refreshing.  The flavor found the same tart oak and lemon throughout.. just enough pale malt to support, but it didnt provide much else.. zesty, refreshing finish.  Medium-bodied and well-carbonated on the palate.. tangy and engaging.. at several times, it kind of felt like a gueuze, and Im all about that.  Excellent brew!

Bomber from Champagne Cellars.  More of a wild ale than a bierede Garde as the spicyness was muted.  The aourness fortunately was udner great control and accompanied food nicely.  taste grew on me.  Bottled in August of this year, it would be interesting to try after some cellaring. Good amount of head and a lace lines.

Bottle at Where the Wild Beers Are. Slightly hazy light yellow pour. Intriguing aroma of pineapple, cherry, and a solid amount of funk. Nice balance of lemon, sour cherry, and vanilla flavors. Moderate tart stickiness. I like the soft sweetness in it.

Batch dated 8-12-10. Picked up a bottle at Jolly Pumpkins Ann Arbor location. Clear golden pour, with a fine white head. The nose is sour, barnyard funkiness. Flavor is very sour, barnyard, wheat, lemongrass, pineapple. Ive been looking for a bottle of this since reading the New York Times review of best Belgian-style beers and saw it listed. I really enjoy Jolly Pumpkins beers, and this one, brewed for Leelanau, is no exception.

Aroma:Smells like a sour farmhouse ale. Lemon, belgian yeast, sulphur.

Appearance:Hazy golden color, with light head and retention. Good lacing.

Taste:Hugely sour beer. Sour citrus, lemon, lime, orange in the foretaste.

Palate:Light body, good carbonation.

Overall:This is quite an interesting sour beer.

08 vintage. Pours a semi hazy yellow color with a large foamy white head. Notes of sheeps wool, lemons, yarn, nectarines, white peaches, slight funk, and vanilla. Slightly sour and tangy mouthfeel. Long finish. Nice beer but not normally what I would think of as a bdg.
Gold and spritzy gold pour, fluffy white head and heavy lace.  Lacto & and wheaty aroma.  Flavor is tart dry and refreshing

On tap at MBGSF 2010. Pale gold color. Tangy, fruity, citrus aroma with a bit of dust and funk. Medium sourness, citrus, and a cracker-like, biscuity malt. A touch of honey. Well done, well-balanced and very tasty.

Pours blonde with a good head and good lace. The aroma is earthy, fruity, and funky with some distinct lemon peel and some hay. The flavor is nicely dry and earthy and slightly sour. The beer reminds me a good bit of Champagne.

Poured at the MBG summer fest 10.  Finally got to try this, not sure what took so long.  Poured a hazy yellow with a small white head.  Aroma was inviting funk, bit of citrus and hay.  Taste is more funk, bit of mustiness, more lemon and a bright refreshing tartness.  Really liked this beer.  More great work by Ron and Co.  Good stuff.

Draft. Pours hazy gold, persistent white skim, spotty lacing. Nose is brandy, citrus, lacto-funk, tart apples. Flavours are well-integrated, and very subtle. Apples, white pepper, tart, light oak, slightly vinous, very nice. Had 2 more servings.
On tap at MBGSF 2010. Served by the Gentleman of Leisure. Tangy, a bit confusing. Moderately sour. Lemony.

Bouteille de 750 ml partagée avec MartinT et le brasseur du Cheval Blanc. Arôme: Légère odeur de citron avec une pointe sûrette. Apparence: La couleur est blonde pâle légèrement voilée. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Léger goût de citron et de coriandre avec une pointe sûrette. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement huileuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence dépices en arrière goût. Merci Martin (Rating #3007)

My Bottom Line:
This fruity Sour Ale harbors white grape and citrusy notes throughout, developing diplomatic sourness in a light wooden finish.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A ring of foam circles the misty golden.
-Lactobacillus is rampant, especially in the nose.
-The grain bill appears simple, even though the bacteria have added quite a bit of motion around these cereals.
-I was expecting more sourness based on the lacto-filled aroma.

Bottle.

750 ml bottle; thanks to goryshkewych for the sweet bonus bottle; dark orange with thin off-white head; nice perfumy nose of lemons, oak, husky grains and a little bit of yeasty funk that seems perfectly jolly pumpkin; drinks with a husky fullness and flavor mix of oats, hay, dried fruit and lemons; slight funk seems a little off at first, but starts to grow on me; musky grains, cookies and lemon; quite nice overall with oak dry finish; yummy

Pours a somewhat cloudy school bus yellow and sporting a thin sheet of white.  Big, sour, and cheesy funk in the nose with added elements of apricot and oak.  Very earthy and woody flavors but very dry and ghost-like on the palate.  Seriously vinious with loads of oaky brett notes.  Warming alcohol...this is actually a quite nice, dry, bretty, warming, and relaxing concoction.

Bottle courtesy of Greg at Birreria Paradiso - thanks Greg!
Cloudy golden color with a medium white head that settles slowly to leave great lacing.  Aroma of sour grapefruit and coriander.  Moderate funk.  Flavor is sour throughout, but with big malts also, and a hint of spice in the background.  Great body and mouthfeel.  Unique and very tasty.

Bottle thanks to ditmier for sharing. Pours out a hazy yellow topped with a white head. Aroma was of wood, fruit, and brett. Taste was more of the same oak, brett, fruits, and sour. Sour I was not expecting this from this style. But it was very tasty.

Bottle.  Pours a cloudy golden yellow with a small white head.  Aroma of funky barnyard, sour candies.  Flavor is tart/sour/funky in the initial sips with sweet sour candies in the finish.  Some dry, lemony hops as well.  Quite tart and acidic.  Biere de Garde?  This was a sour ale all the way...
7/4/7/4/15 [3.7/5]

At first i didnt understand this beer, but it has grown to be my all-time favorite. Some bottles are better than others, depending on batch, age in cellar, how its handled, the weather and setting, ect; but really, its always fantastic. Notes of herbs, peaches and barrel funk in the aroma appear in the in the mouth too, but that just scratches the surface of everything going on.

750mL bottle, no date.  Effervescent clear golden body with a three finger rocky white head, great retention.  Lemon juice (not the shitty BHT-ridden stuff--the real thing) and leather up front with some old wooden barrel and pale malt notes.  I know this isnt a new bottle, but I feel like I get some green herbal hops mixed in as well as some light peach/apricot.  Flavor has some stronger lemon notes as well as some alcohol.  It seems a little more peachy as well, with a hint of oxidation (wet paper).  Slight alcohol burn in the dry finish--this wasnt sweet at all (other than the peachy notes).  Moderate to high carbonation with a medium body.  Good beer--Ive had this a couple few times now, the other ratings will be inputted when I finally enter my notebooks.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Bottle thanks to ditmier, the first of the night! Pours a clear yellow color with a medium white fluffy head. The aroma is complex; woody and sour, but also some funk and apricots. A tart and woody flavor with some fruity and funkiness. An awesome take on the style.

2009 Bottle - Thanks coyotehunter! - Pours a hazy golden with a large white head...aroma is gorgeous, wood, citrus, brett...flavour is similar, nicely tart without being sour, tropical fruit, oak, floral and lightly malted...this rocked!

Yellow-gold uniform color with very little carbonation and a small white head.  Slow lacing.  Pineapple and med. sharp cheddar in nose.  Cheddar apparent on foretongue and in aftertaste.  Tastes like sour blackberries mixed with honey and muskodines.

Where the Wild Beers Are @ The Gate 8/30/09.  Hazy yellow with ring.  Hay melon perfumy aroma.  Melon grapfruit hay barn mild funk.  Nice soft palate.  Not really sour or woody for some reason.  Good.

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2010 Re-rate.  Bottle.  Pours a hazy gold with a thick white head. Really nice crisp lemony citrus and soft funky brett.  Really nice aroma on this. Medium bodied, smooth, and lightly sweet with a nice musk and a big lemony acid.  Finishes with some more musk and a touch of alcohol.  Really glad I gave this one another try.  First time I had a small sample, this time I got a whole bottle to myself.  Really good.

Original rating: 3.4 - 637315Bottle at the Where the Wild Beers are event. Hazy gold, thin white head.  Light brett, lemon.  Sweet, light funk, bretty.  Finishes dry and somewhat empty.

Bottle from coyotehunter.  Thanks so much, Matt!  I absolutely love these Leelanau brews, I cant wait for Ron to make some more!  This one was no different.   Great pour, terrific nose-- pineapple, lemon tart. Really yummy BdG.

Thanks a bunch to Terminus for sharing this one.  Pours cloudy golden / orange with a whitish head.  The aroma has smooth creamy wheat, mildly earthy hops and some esters.  Very light body compared to the aroma with sharp underscored carbonation.  The flavor is way different than the aroma showed.  There is a sweet / tart taste with lemon, funk, sourness, graininess and a good deal of spice.  The finish is lingering biting sourness and citric as can be.  An excellent beer.

Bottle 75cl. @ Papsoes blindtasting. [ Bottle #2. ]Unclear medium yellow orange color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy citrus tart, fruity, acidic apricot - green apples. Flavor is moderate sweet to heavy and moderate acidic with a long duration, and a dry dry finish. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft to flat. [20090501]
Enjoyed. Tasted like a regular JP without all the spice. Lots of brett that seems to mellow out as I sip it down.

Clear golden with a medium white head. Sweet fruity aroma with yeasty and brett notes. Sour flavour with lacto, sour lemons and grapefruit notes. Flavour was sour with lacto, brett, lemons, grapefruit and woody notes. Finished sour.

Sampled from 750 ml bottle during Dark Lord Day 09, at table 3. Pours a semi-clear light golden straw colored brew with a thin white head that slowly dissipates and leaves behind some nice lacing. Aroma of light caramel malt, some pear/apple fruit, a hint of honey, and a touch of figs. Taste is medium to full bodied, smooth, with flavors of caramel malt, honey, a touch of flowery hops, and some alcohol. Finish is semi-sweet with a caramel/fruit aftertaste.

Bottle 75 cl. Courtesy of yespr. Hazy yellow with a creamy white head leaving laces. Lightly tart Brett aroma. Light body, pale malts, tart fruitiness, a whiff of green apples and an astringent and lactic dry finish. Nice one. 010509

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2009 Thanks a ton Sam for letting me try this again.  Pours a pale hazy straw gold with a one finger frothy white head. Aroma is very dense and layered. Pineapple comes out upfront, definite funky character, yeasty, floral, mild honey in the aroma, sweet and peachy as it warms. Flavor shows earthy honey, tart pineapple juice, fruity esters, oaky tannic bite, muscadine grapes come out at some point. Palate is tart with a nice crisp acidity. Fantastic.
Oh hot damn, this is good. Light hazy golden pour with big rocky white head. Sour barrel fruit (lots of canned pineapple) and funky yeast.  Good citrus, and quite tart.  Refreshing and fun.  Yum.

Bottled. A hazy light golden beer with a bit of sediment floating around under a thin white head. The aroma is acidic with notes of citrus and brettanomyces. The flavor is acidic with notes of citrus and brettanomyces as well as light notes of wheat, leading to a lightly tart finish.
Sampled at WBF in Raleigh.  Pours a light yellow reminiscent of a witbier.  Pleasant sour aroma.  Balanced golden ale taste with just the right mix of sourness.  Very well done.

#2 at papsø blind tasting
cloudy yellow,s mall white head.
aroma is citrussy, slight stable, brett.
flaov r is a mix between stable, brett. also slight citrussy.

#2
Bottle. [Papsoe grand American tasting] Average light fin bubbled white head that mostly lasted. Fair display of lacework. Light cloudy pale golden color. Aroma of sour fruity notes with some citrus and dry mild spicy feel. Somewhat milky feel over the palate as well as light rubber. Medium bodied with a soft carbonation and light dry pepper like burning texture. Medium acidic and sweet flavor. Lingering spicy sour finish. 7 / 4 / 7 / 3 / 14 = 3.5

From bottle, Papsoes blindtasting #2, courtesy of Jeppe. Pours cloudy yellow with a small white head. Mild fruity and light acetone like aroma, vague wheaty note. Citric and dry sourish flavured. Vague residual wheaty sweetness and light yeasty touch. Dry and citric brett-ish flavoured finish. Fresh and vague acetone like lasting impression.
DLD tasting.  Hazy yellow pour.  White head.  Aroma of floral hops, malty sweetness.  Flavor is woody, malty a bit of sweetness with a nice hop bite at the end.  Not bad.

Name: Good Harbor Goldent
Date: April 25, 2009
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting, DLD
Appearance: cloudy yellow, fine white head, streaks of lace
Aroma: sweet and spicy aroma, light malt sweetness, lots of spicy hops
Flavor: sweet malt flavor, lots of oak and spicy hops, light bitterness
Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 12/20
Rating: 3/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: *4

random bottle bocky pulled out to give us a break from the imperial stouts...
pours hazy but bright yellow like a childs finger painting of sunny (wtf? i actually wrote that in my notes?)... with a soft white head which leaves behind a lot of spotty drippy lacing.

smells oddly like canned peaches... sweet pale fruit, cinnamon/spiciness, wood, dirt and minerals with a bit of sour grain in the back. 

a light sourness is present on the palate akin to watered down lemon juice... dusty wheaty grain, stony minerals, warm wood and some spice/pepper before that funky bretty yeast catches up on the finish. 

the medium body is a bit chalky in the mouth. a pleasant acidity and sudsy carbonation clean the palate off quite well. neat-o... 8/4/7/4/16/3.9

From out of the depths of the bockyhorsey stash as a respite from all of the imperial stouts we were sampling. Pours a golden light pils color. Aroma is of bleu cheese, mild vomit, and predominant vinegar. Taste is marred by too much carbonation. There is some kind of sourness and hops behind all that. Palate cleansing and tasty after spending way too long working the bubbles out.

Bottle. Pours a murky golden color with a minimal white head. Lots of carbonation. Aroma is of mild oak, cherries, hops, yeast, and grain. Taste starts off with lots of oak and tart cherries, followed by yeast, hops, grain, and acidic citrus. Mouthfeel is light and crisp. Very refreshing with a nice sour bite. Again for these Leelanua beers, its good but not $12 good.

Hazy gold with good, creamy white head / JP funky, clothes closet and sour fruit nose / Light to medium body, very tart, with good finish / Sour flavors of lemon, barnyard straw, grass, pineapple, passionfruit, funky brett, and oak / Not on a par with JPs own brews, but real good.

Clear yellow gold pour with a big, effervescent, white head that fades quickly to a thin layer.  Smells of cereal, pear, Belgian yeast, and the classic JP sour funk.  The flavor is not far off the aroma but with a much more dominant, lemony, acidic, sour kick.  This is a real sour beer lovers beer.  Its not very far off from a good geuze in that it really has that great balance of wheat malt and sour funk.  This would make a great replacement for champagne and a very good pairing with fish, Mediterranean, and grilled chicken.

Sampled at the Bockyhorsey tasting, courtesy of Bockeyhorsey.  Slightly hazy golden color pour with a foamy head.  Aroma of grain, malt and funky yeast.  Lots of wheat, yeast and sour citrus in the flavor.  Some spice comes through on the finish.  A very nice, refreshing brew.

Sampled from Bottle at Bockys. Fermented yeasty along with wheat grain. Gold body with white foamy head. Flavor had an acidic bitter wheat flavor to it. Beer was a truley a good refreshment to the palate after the 6 samples of Impy stouts before this brew. Thanks to Styles for sending this one to me.

Bottle at Bockys, forget who brought this but thanks! Pours a golden yellow with a huge foamy white head. Aroma of asprin , funk, some sourness. Flavor is sour, funky, lemon, grass, wheat, yeasts. Very nice funky biere de garde.

Bottle bought at Gingerman- thanks to beastiefan2k for sharing!  Pours a nice slightly hazy golden with a fluffy typical lasting jp head.  Aroma is nicely funky but not out of control like on some bottles- a bit doughy yeasty, crackery, and lightly spiced- some phenolic funk.  Wheaty creamy flavor with a nice citrusy tartness in the end- good spiciness all around with some mineral salt and of course some brett funkl.  Nice smooth finish and good body throughout.
Definitely a bit funky. Very light characters in the flavor, wheat, floral notes. Tartness throughout. Nose not too strong, funky yeast, wheat.

750ml bottle. Similar to a wit on the nose. Sweet wheat and a touch of funk. Bugged oak. Perfume. Fresh flower bouquet. A slight fruit component... mango perhaps? Overall, sweeter malted wheat and mildly funky barrel. Pours a bright, hazed gold with a thick, creamy white head. Flavor has a lot of wheat characteristics. Green apple. Oak. Funky yeast. Doughy malt. Honestly, there isnt much to it, but the beer is quite delicious and insanely drinkable. Leaning toward full bodied for the style. Slightly lactic on the tongue. Creamy with a cereal maltiness on the finish. Like all the other Leelanau beers... delicious, drinkable and a good dose of Cap. Ron barreling.
Light yellow and cloudy with a good sized white head. Aroma is of grapes, spices, apple, yeast, and wood. Flavor is of grapes, tart apples, and spices.

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2009 Bottle at home - New Years Tasting. Cloudy yellow - white head. Wheaty, citrus, horsey, brett, soapy, orange, light wood, fruity. High carbonation..... Again: #02 - Amerikaner Smagning 01-Maj-2009 hos Papsoe. Wet dog, brett, soapy, licorice, yeasty, citric, milkey, bitterness, zesty. (6/3/7/3/14)

Bottle with thw Club. Pours a hazy pale yellow with a white head and lacings. Smells sour and of malts. Tastes sour with aromas of citrus fruits and malts. Very high carbonation. This one might be better on a sunny day on the beach.

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2009 Bottle #2 at Papsøs blindtasting.
Hazy yellow cloured with black floaties and a medium sized white head.
Fruity aroma of brett with an acidic touch and notes of citrus.
Fruity flavour of brett and citrus with notes of barnyard and an acidic touch.
Tart finish.

Uklar gul farve med et lille hvidt skum. Duft af citrus, mærkelige frugter og gær. Smager af sæbe og citrus og er ikke særlig humlet. Kort syrlig eftersmag og godt med bobler. Efter disse 3 øl er der dømt sure opstød i stor stil.
I really enjoyed this beer....a bit of sour that I really think balances the sweetness quite well......I could drink the hell out of this...
Light hazy yellow color.  Sharper on the nose than others.  Tart.  I kept coming back to this one at AlohaCs tasting.  Thanks to WeeHeavy(I think).
Tried at alohaCs 2008 end of the year tasting. Cloudy light yellow.  Interesting orange peel citrusy aroma.  Easy to drink.  Very nice.
Golden color with a gentle aroma of light citrus and sourness with some stone fruits and spices poking through.  Flavor is mildly sour yet full bodied with some spices, oak, and cider.  Nice!

Bottle at the Gingerman, New York, 21-11-08 that Beastiefan purchased and shared with us, cheers mate. I wrote up my description in the lovely little notebook that Garthicus kindly gave me, it also had a lovely little torch pen that whilst tempermental for some worked fine for me now I will never had a problem finding my way home on a dark winters night all thanks to Garthicus and his pen torch, cheers mate. Pours hazy lemon in colour with an off white head. Really good wet wooly aroma, good solid crunch to this beer, big juicy Bramley apples, nice bite really tangy blooming marvellous, can Jolly Pumpkin do anything wrong A7 A4 F7 P4 OV17
Smell is fruit, light wine like, oak, spices, and yeasty.  Cloudy light golen in color with a light white foamy head.  Taste is fruity, some spices, some oak, and yeast.

750ml bottle, shared this with me by Beastiefan2000 Appearance: Yellow & hazy with a large head. Aroma, Sour and juicy,apples and pears, absolutely mouth watering. Flavour - Wow, Sour, juicy, fruity, lip-smacking. Quite tart, a wonderful brew.

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2009 In short: An extra-sharp semi-funky blonde ale.  Very Good.
How: Bottle 750ml, about 5 months old
The look: Cloudy yellow body topped by a medium white head with medium retention 
In long: Nose is medium funky, this is nowhere as wild as Leelanau White Whale.  From the nose this is more like a farmhouse Saison than a funky/bretty Jolly Pumpkin/Leelanau beer.  Taste is rather hard-hitting for such a low abv beer.  Aggressive carbonation, sharp spicy bitter hops, crisp honeyed biscuits, pineapples, strong minerals sensation, some lemon, a little oily.  That beer felt like a Sprite blended with a semi-funky ale.  The beer is rather dry and tart.  As it warmed up lemony meringue was becoming a dominant flavour.  This is a very good beer but considering Leelanau/Jolly Pumpkin line-up I was expecting James Brown funkiness but I got something that was well executed, effective, straightforward, and as funky as AC/DC.

750ml bottle from west lakeview....golden hazy yellow brown pour with a thin white head...
the nose comprised up of citrus and pineapple aroma with a light tartness...
crisp, lively lemony citrus flavors with a tart dry finish.  good carbonation and very drinkable to say the least.
8/4/7/4/14-15

750ml Bottle:  Aroma of Brett yeast, tart fruit, slight funk, and lemon-lime citrus.  Aroma tart enough to make my mouth water.  Poured pale yellow/light gold/flaxen in color with no head.  Cloudy.  Very sparkling.  Some medium-sized particles.  Flavor is very tart.  Tastes like a sour ale.  Flavors of citrus, tart fruit, and hints of blueberry and bubblegum.  Medium body.  Tingly, effervescent texture.  Lively carbonation.  Tart, saliva-producing finish.

A hazy, yellowish-golden body is topped with a mountain of dense, craggy foam that sticks around for ages.  Thick, foamy sheets and flares of lacing coat the glass very well.  Abundant, effervescing bubbles constantly feed the foamy crown.  The aroma shows a pilsner malt base, sweet and doughy, along with chardonnay grapes, lemongrass, orchard fruits, lavender, and heaps of bready yeast.  The oak influence is soft, imparting more of a light woody scent than the typical vanilla notes.  Similarly, the bretty funk is on the mild side.  Flavors are very similar, vinous chardonnay, sweet bready malts, crisp lemongrass, and musty oak all showing through.  Apples and grapes lend tartness, while flowers and herbs add perfumy, spicy depth.  The mouthfeel is substantial and lightly fizzy, with a semi-dry, bretty finish that lingers.  This might be the most herbal of all the Jolly Pumpkins, and the brett presence milder than most.  Interesting brew.  Quite nice.

(750ml bottle)  Pours a hazy golden body with a medium white head.  Aroma of mustiness, floral, grass, citrus, chardonnay grapes, butter, and apple.  Flavor of chardonnay, grass, yeast, lemon, some funkiness, and light herbs with an oak finish.

Bottle. Pours a hazy, dark gold with a thin white head that lingers. Sour, sharp aroma, with malt and fruit. Taste is sweet and sour then finishes clean and a little watery, with yeast and malt, a hint of preserved lemons. Light lingering sourness. Tasty.
bottle at Beer Exposed, thanks to Phil_l.  Lovely aroma, really lovely slightly lmeony lime and very tart orange.  pretty awesome.  Bit too much citrus acid in mouth, too tart, and lacks a bit.
bottle thanks to bu11zeye.  murky yellow pour with a thin white head.  slight sourness on the nose with some spices.  very smooth on the palate with some sour notes and a very carbonated finish.

Bottle thanks to bu11zeye. Pours with a clear yellow body and a fluffy white head that leaves good lacing and sticks around for a while. Aroma is spicey and vinous, with chardonnay like characteristics and a bit of apple. The taste has some enital Jolly Pumpkin tart funkiness, followed by apples and a continued vinous qualty. Slightly fizzy and dry to style.

My first Bière de Garde thanks to Bu11zeye. Pours a hazy yellow with white head. Aroma of chardonnay, apple, lemon. Flavor is very citris, lemon, apple, as well as chardonnay. Light body with high carbonation. Good stuff!, would like to drink again, goes down easy.

Bottle at beer exposed, many thanks to Phil_l. All i see is golden ale and im like, "enough of this pish, gee us a swally". However it turns out to be a far superiour beast than The Cad had ever reconed for. Big lemon character, theres some candy sweetness, loads of fruityness, but not estery and cloying, tart and very very drinkable. I pestered phil so much i got like 3 samples.

A Mes rate: bottle at Beer Exposed thanks to our Phil.Nothing much like your regular BDG but this is a fine drop no doubt. Straw coloured with a thin but lasting Persil white head. Awesome tarty citrus just falls out of the glass and invites you in. This was the last good day of the summer and this beer really suited it. The JP influences are clear. Chewy damp wood notes deliver the excellent bitter hoppage really well. The spritzy and zesty finish is a real smack round the chops but it washes away beautifully to a lingering, delicately sweet malty after taste smoothing it out nicely. This is a very interesting beer and rather bloody lovely.

Bottle @ Beer Exposed, September 2008.
[thank you, Phil_L]
[my 3,900th rating!!!]
Pours pale golden with a small, frothy, white, film head. Aroma has lots of brett, some malts and citric acid. Fine, very dry mouthfeel. The flavour is lovely tart, citric, sticks to my teeth, some barnyard, malts and lemond. A touch of lactic acid and wood with a subdued caramel in the finish. Very delicious.

Thanks to RagallachMC for the 750. Straw color and mostly clear. Medium head. Aroma of citrus, wheat, sour white grapes and brett. A little oaky flavor sneaks in, but you know its Jolly Pumpkin brewed by the brett. This beer surprised the hell out of me. Such a non-descript bottle holding such a classy brew.
Aroma is funky fruit, barnyard, wet blanket, hazy golden, pours a tiny white head. Flavour is mild fruit with nice malt tones. Tangy, spicy, good tongue tingle. Lovely. Thanks Torontoblue.

UPDATED: SEP 30, 2008 Bottle... Post RBSG 08 O-Town/Vero Beach Throwdown Chapter 8... Hazy, straw-colored ale with a small, fizzy, white head. Decent retention. The aroma is tart with notes of pale grains and spent mash. Medium to full-bodied with fizzy carbonation. Tangy, tart flavor. Crisp, acidic finish. Thanks to JMFG for providing the bottle!

A light golden hue fills my glass and a creamy poufy white head makes her presence known. Fading into a light ring and quaint brussels lace with each swirl, I raise my glass to my lips to quaff my very first Biere de Garde, Good Harbor Golden. First her nose; crisp bitter lemon, fresh almost rank sourdough mingles with summer apples and fresh pear. Her body is light and fruity as it caresses my tongue and leaves a more sweet impression on my palate then her initial sour assault. Airy with nice carbonation. After a while, Good Golden Harbor settles into a smooth, effervescent brew with a sweet and sour blend of lemons, sourdough, and apples. A pleasant finish for my first time.

I have no other Biere de Gardes to compare the Good Harbor Golden from Leelanau Brewing too, but what I did taste I enjoyed. Very reminiscent of saisons, yet still able to stand on her own, I look forward to meeting more of her varied and widespread sisters.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2008 750 from Daleliz, thanks again Liz.  Pours golden with a bright white head.  Nose is sweet and bright with a nice complexity.  Really tasty citrus with a very nice complex flavor and a great aftertaste that gets me to continue to want to take another sip.  Yummy.

Hazy straw color with a moderate, somewhat dissipating bright white head that ends up being a etched glass looking coating and a bit of lace. Funky aromas with notes of brett, oak, wheat and underneath it all some tropical fruit.  The more I sniff the more I catch some malt liquor qualities with heavy malt and a hint of alcohol. Light sweet start, a triple type sweetness that carries throughout. Some sweet floral hops work there way in the middle. More tart than sour, but yet there are some sweet sour flavors. Quite quenching for a brew this formidable. A loaf of bread, some cheese and this in a basket would make for a great afternoon in the countryside.

Pours a hazy straw yellow.  I bought this bottle on whim and did not know what to expect.  To my surprise it is quite tart.
Woody and bretty, has a green apple skin tannin.  Real tasty and light on the palate.

Slightly murky straw color, moderately thick big-bubbled head.  Mild JP citric funk aroma over mild spicy grains.  Moderate brett tartness on the taste, sweet grain, apples, oak.  Subtle, but damn tasty.

Straw coloured and cloudy.  Nose of pediococcus, wood and a little brett.  Taste is pedio, wood, brett, too.  Hint of tartness...fun stuff...not too different from other soury funky American experiments but I like it.

This beer is contract brewed at Jolly Pumpkin.

Pours clear gold, with a light chill haze. A three-inch head of dense white sank slowly, and a partial skim-coat remained for the duration. A few strings of lacework also.

Aromatics are lemony, hay-like, and brightly acidic. Slightly lactic, with plenty of wheat twang and grapefruit.

Light bodied and crisp. Tart and quenching mouthfeel.

The pallet delivers what the nose promised. Lemon zest, wet hay, grapefruit pith, and clean acid. Slightly prickly on the back of the throat.

Finishes with plenty of lemony tartness and cut grass on the farm.

This ones a bit cleaner than the JP brews in that the lactic quality is minimal, while the acid is bright and clean. Some more funk would be nice, especially some brett.
Mildly sour in comarison to an authentic lambic or other American wild ales, but certainly more sour than any Biere de Garde.
Pretty damn tasty on a hot summer’s eve.

bottle shared by JMFG: pours a great golden hay colour with a good white head. aroma is a good funk, slight lemon, barrel, adn a good amount of malts too. flavour is a tart citrus flavour , again with good funkiness and some of the barrel, slight lemon good ber.
At Vero. Hazy pale yellow with small off-white head. Pedio funk aroma. Smooth soft mouthfeel. Pedio, smooth, seed oil. Smooth, relatively simple and very nice.

Bottle courtesy of JMFG. Pours cloudy hay color with white head. Sour, funky aroma. Sour and sweet flavors with some funkiness and oak also. Medium body with average carbonation. It has that signature Jollly Pumpkin flavor to it. A very nice beer.

Pours hazy golden, rich white head with good retention. Aroma is woody, somewhat musty with a hint of sweet fruit and a noticeable suggestion of sourness. Flavor starts quite sweet, then develops a woody sourness that lingers through a long sour finish. Fairly light mouthfeel with light carbo. Really nice. I’m told this is actually a Jolly Pumpkin beer, which doesn’t surprise...chalk another one up in their column!

Hazy gold with a frothy white head. Nice aroma is spicy, cracker malts with a whiff of barnyard funk and wood. Frothy expansive mouthfeel. Mildly sour  with flavors of dusty pale malts, dry wood and tart lemon and spices.  A nicely complex pale brew here.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: 22oz bottle. Let me say right off the bat that I knew this was brewed by JP. You can absolutely taste it. Nose is tart and crazy with hints of straw and citrus bit of cherry and lemon. Sweet and slightly woody to start with some vanilla and caramel and big tart notes. Lemony but not soapy. This is a very cool Bier de Garde.

Pour is slightly hazed golden with a thin dense and sticky white head...smell is lightly fruity and sweet with pears and lemons....some corn too...taste is lightly sweet at first, with a light but consistent tartness and almost citric in nature...nice tart finish....interesting for a BdG, but delicious and not surprising for Ron!

A softer pour produces an almost three-finger thick, pale, off-white colored head.  The beer is a light honey / gold color that shows a hazy, straw-gold color when held up to the light.  The head leaves a layered lacing pattern on the sides of my glass as I work my way through this beer.  The aroma has a bright, grassy grain character to it, a certain soft mustiness and even a hint of something like barnyard funk (though only the beginning stages of this last).  Fruit aromatics of pear and tart, slightly under-ripe plum also play a significant role as does some floral and herbal aromatics that add a nice edge to the nose.  This has quite a complex nose to it that makes this quite interesting and quite enjoyable to smell.

Still well carbonated, despite losing a quarter of its contents en route to me (which really means it must have started out excessively carbonated).  The carbonation provides a nice textural component as well as accenting a peppery note that adds to the overall spiciness of this brew.  This is quite spicy too with fermentation derived notes of ginger, white pepper and higher alcohols which all combine to give this brew a sort of piquancy.  This has a nice, light tartness to it, but not much in the way of sweetness; the tartness accentuates fruit flavors of pear, melon and a certain character that makes me thing of some floral honey varietal.  The higher alcohols provide a touch of heat to the finish at times, almost a bit like a spicy ginger or horse-radish would.  This is highly quaffable and in fact drinks lighter than your typical 7.5% abv beer would.  

This is a very enjoyable brew, I wouldn’t really characterize it as a Bier de Garde, but many of Jolly Pumpkin’s style designations are by inspiration only anyway.  Still this is quite a tasty brew, one which I am happily quaffing.  This doesn’t seem to have anything beyond a normal Belgian yeast strain funkiness to it (despite the notes in the nose), though it is certainly a characterful strain at the very least.

Bottle (750ml) shared with HogTownHarry, biegaman, rudolf & swoopjones -- courtesy of rudolf. Pours a cloudy pale yellow with an average size diminishing white head. Aroma: Oh yeah! Funky, citrusy and spicy! Awesome. Flavour’s funky, tart and spicy along with some bready malt, wood, sweetness and a slightly odd, long acidic finish. Average to medium bodied. Very good stuff.

750ml bottle. pours hazy golden with big foamy white head. aroma is classic jolly pumpkin bretty funk and sourness. initially rather spritzy, lemon and orange, oak, with a spicy and acidic finish that mellows on the back of the throat. spritzy high carbonation. light body. this is right up there with the other JP brews.

Bottle from Maxbauer’s After Hours.Pours a foggy yellow, like a lighthouse giving hope to seafarers from afar.  Aroma is a blend of zesty lemon peel and lemon candy, with a touch of champagne (or is it sparkling wine).  Flavor is a mouth-puckering blend of lemon, coriander, lemon, and lemon.  Lively mouthfeel from a brew that simply won’t die on the tongue.  A fantastic biere de garde; almost good enough to take my mind off my dog’s passing.   But there ain’t a beer in the world that can make me forget my Buster boy.

text: Bottle, shared at Cole’s.  Gold, light chill haze.  Thin white head.  Nose is sweet tarts, lemon, honey, lavender, peach, brett.  Flavor is light brett, lemon, a bit tart with wood, bretty cherry.  Tartness grows as it warms.  Finish is sweet tarts & brett, floral.  Wonderful.

Bottle (750ml).  Shared by rudolf with blankboy, biegaman and swoopjones.  Thanks for the share, Rudy!  Poured pale cloudy yellow with a small white head.  Near-heavenly aroma of funky yeast, lemon, sour citrus up front with plenty of heavy fruit/sweet malt in behind (8+).  The taste followed right on, but lighter than the aroma, sweeter, with honey more than balancing the lemon/citrus tartness, but still a long acidic finish.  Sticky mouthfeel, nicely carbonated, plenty of tingling acidity in the aftertaste - ultimately a tad light, but a terrific drinkin sour.

Bottle with Rudolf, HogTownHarry, Blankboy & Biegaman. Thanks Rudolf for sharing. Aroma is full of barnyard funkiness & spiciness. Some lemony citrus also. {Pretty basic pale yellow color. Taste is funky, slightly sour & tartness. Taste was decent but didnt live up to the great aroma. Refreshing tasting & very easy drinking

750ml bottle.  Aroma:  Lemons, cherries, light funk and pepper, oak and vanilla.  Really nice.  Appearance:  Pale gold in color and hazy.  White head was full and frothy with good retention.  Fair lacing.  Flavor:  Some light graininess, lemon and green grapes, dusty funk, oak.  Really nice tartness throughout.  Tartness and dry finish make it refreshing.  Palate:  Medium-light bodied.  Medium carbonation.  Overall:  Really tasty and a pleasure to drink.  This would be a great beer to quench the thirst after a hot day.

A great Biere de Garde. Not as sweet as most. Aroma of funk, lemon and sugar. Pour was a nice cloudy gold with a 2 finger white head. Taste was nice and dry. A tart beginning with some lemon and yeast in the aftertaste. Mouth dries after the swallow and leaves a nice saison like tartness. Great beer.

I cant believe it has taken me so long to sample this. Incredibly refreshing and tastes nothing like 7.5%; I would have thought 5%. Delicious! Beautiful color and slight head, thinnish body.

text: Bottle.  Pours a golden body with a light white lacing.  Aroma is ginger oakiness with a moderate pear aroma.  Flavor is spicy with a moderate amount of sweet malt.  decent.
750ml bottle: I really liked this beer.  Pours yellow with a thick head.  Sour aroma and flavor.  Very good.
cloudy yellow pour with a thin white head.  Strong oak and yeast aroma.  Flavor was more of the same,  a bit of vinager and some tannins.  Finishes acidic,  well done.
Hazy pale yellow hue with a white head.  Fruity with a sour skunky off flavor.  Fizzy palate and light in body.  Sour and fruity with yeasty funk.  Ick,

750ml bottle courtesy of heemer. Thanks Eric. Poured a cloudy light yellow color. The head was fizzy, white, and didnt leave much lace behind. Smelled of white wine, oak, yeasty bread dough, and subdued vinegar. Very effervescent and fairly acidic on the tongue. Vinous and oaky flavors with  a good splash of warm alcohol. I liked this one.

Bottle. The body was bright hazy gold with a white head. The aroma was sour lemons with some funky blue cheese. The taste was sour and dry wood. There was also some tart apples. Crisp and refreshing. A more sour version of the style and well made.

750ml bottle acquired in trade with Styles (thanks!). Poured a medium and hszy yellow color with a small sized white head. Aromas of citrus (lemons), vanilla, cherries, apples, and sood. Tastes of citrus, cherries, green apples, wood, vanilla, and a little funky.

Poured a hazy golden color with a medium sized white head that left light lacing on the glass.  Aroma of brett, oak, vanilla, wild yeast, citrus, and apple.  Taste of citrus, green apple, oak, vanilla, and a lightly sour finish.

Thanks to hopdog for sharing this one.  Pours a hazy golden with a smaller bubbly white head.  Aroma of vanilla, tart cherry, lemon, apple juice, oak, some medicinal notes.  Flavor of tart cherries, some funky notes, oak, vanilla, lots of citrus notes and some peaches.

Golden colored, as one might expect. Smells lemony, citrusy and spicy, with herbal and winey notes. Flavor is really nice - citrus and tart, an underlying note of white wine, and a lot of subtle spices mixed in. Very tasty and refreshing.

Bottle, shared by beastiefan2k.  Gold pour with some white head.  Aroma is oaky, a little leathery, some pale sweet belgian malt, and citrus.  The flavor is somewhat funky from the oak, but there isnt a whole lot else of note... maybe nice balance with the malt.  Some citrus also.

750mL Bottle. Thanks Sean! Salty, low-lying malt aroma. A bit of dusty breath carries through some light Brett and grain reductions. Pours a crystal clear, really dense rich gold, a truly brazen sun and lemon yellow. Fuming bubbles. A lilting, rocky opalescent white head floats above.  Flavor is soft, smooth and generally agreeable. A wheat cracker is glazed with lemon curd. Soft alcohols, balanced acidity. Explosive. Fresh. Salty. A very plain, soft grassy beer. Theres not an exceptional amount of beer. But the wildness blends well and the malt sugars are clean and straight forward. A clean acidity. Ragingly drinkable. Parches the palate and leaves me refreshed. A nice rendition, but lacking necessary complexity.
750ml bottle. Very light pale color. Smells like white wine. very sour, and very sweet. It was almost like a liquid sweetart with alcohol. Interesting.

pours gold with a nice white head.  tart, lambic-ish nose, with sweet notes.   citrus and acetic acid in the flavor,  with pepper.   bubbly mouth fell with dry finish.  not a fan of the style, but this one is not too bad.

Pours a foggy straw with a thin off white head. Nose is a good level of funky that carries an almost lambic kind of nose at first. Slight fruit tone. Dies off to a more earthy and subdued woody character. Flavor brings a severe complexity. The first thing I think is cheese (most specifically brie). Why bother picking up half a pound at the Bedford cheese shop when you can get it here. Actually. It just makes me want to take a bite out of some hunk of cheesy goodness. Great thinner mild fruit tones. Body is very nice. Smooth carbonation on a consistent liquid body. Extremely drinkable. I dont usually like this style, but this is good. Definitely unique. The most memorable beer I have had in quite some time.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2008 This is a beautiful beer. Very active bright white head and the beer radiated a lemony glow. Tasted a little tart/lemony, too, but also delicious cereal maltiness and a touch of funk. Has some sweetnes, too, then finishes dry and oaky. The golden grain maltiness lingered, too. This is what I hoped Ommegeddon would taste like.

750mL bottle, courtesy of yjb.  Thanks, Yaniv!  Pours a hazy, whitish-honey color; fluffy, bright-white head with great retention and lacing coating the glass; an ideal pour.  Very pleasant aroma: mild brett presence, lemony dish soap, honey, and wheat; a fair amount of tartness perfectly integrated into a dry, dense background.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: nice jolt of brettiness and zesty citrus at the forefront; good levels of acidity, tartness, and fullness of flavor; perhaps a bit over-carbonated, which serves to cover up a bit of the citrus and honey and sugar within; lots of wheat coming through mid-palate; a drinkable, refreshing, tart beer, but the carbonation begins to detract a bit after the first few sips; sharp on the tongue.  Medium finish showing lemons and additional citrus and some honey; a bit of doughiness comes through at the very end.

Cloudy golden beer with an effervescent body and frothy, thick lacing - semi-tart, kind of wheaty aroma, with some wildflower kicking around back there, along with some lemony smells and a bit of spice - fairly dry and tart, with strong oak flavor - some grainy, wheaty character arrives late, and mildly sour citrus/lemon rind - mild funkiness, wild qualities - a brief hint of sweetness and floral hints - not so much a biere de garde as a tart belgian ale, but pretty decent either way.

An interesting beer, for sure.  Brightly colored golden-hue.  Frothy white head with a very active rising of bubbles.  Quite musty and heavily cellared.  Not too sweet at all.  Tart and has a Belgian/pilsner qualities to it that make it quite unique.

UPDATED: OCT 8, 2008 Before opening the bottled I noticed chunks of goopy crap in the head space of the bottle. Looks the wild yeast is doing something in there! 

Smells like a big ol hunk of blue cheese, and tastes even funkier. The taste is bretty and acidic, but well balanced with sweet malts, and a surprising amount of hoppiness. Fruity and tart. Over carbonated and a bit too full in the mouth for the style. Dont know if Id quite call it a Biere De Garde, but call it what you wanna call it, its tasty.

750 ml bottle
I brought this to the tasting to kick things off with an easy palateable beer before the heavy stuff came out.  As soon as we had a quorom this was popped open.  Immediately a huge gush of foam surged over the top before we could get it to the sink.  It continued to do so until about half the bottle was poured out.  This was a great sessionable beer that one could easily drink alone.  Im not sure I would do so at $9.99 a bottle though.
Aroma / Appearance - The cloudy golden body left a bubbly two finger head, most of which was from the gushing head.  Honey, wheat and a slight hoppiness gave it a great but simple aroma.
Flavor / Palate - The taste flows quickly over the tongue so it takes a while to pick up the light lemon and honey flavors.  It does not intrude at all, quickly getting out of the way.  I found it to be relatively solid but it did not set my world on fire.  This is worth a try if you want a change of pace from big beers but otherwise there might be better ways to spend a ten dollar bill.

10th Columbus Tasting (Christmas 2007) I caught the warm tail end of hte bottle with extra sediment: Thus very yeasty with strong lemon rind nose and taste.  Would make an excellent pairing with seafood--just a thought.

text: sitting under an oak tree, drinking some sweet tea. its so dry. i pick up a twig and start chewing on it.

From a 750mL Bottle.  Obtained in a trade with Ogglethorp, 10/2007.  Pours a mostly transparent, ripened banana gold color with a finger of white frothy head.  Funky brett aroma of leather, sour lemons, barnyard, and hints of tropical fruit, mainly pineapple.  There seems to be a subtle residual sugar sweetness as well, as the nose already doesnt seem as dry as most JP beers.  Medium light bodied, creamy wheat malt body with a spritzy, prickly carbonation and a mild acidity.  Fairly dry, but has a noticeable pale malt sweetness up front on the palate.  Lightly tart, with funky sour lemon flavors and a mild phenolic spice.  More pineapple.  Pretty tasty overall, but the musty brett funk and dry oak characters seem to clash a bit with the malt body; I think a bit more dryness would help round it out some more.  Thanks, Brian!

Bottle. Golden pour with a white head. Aroma of light sour, a bit of funk, lemon/lemon zest. Flavors od light citrus, lemon zest, sour, and a bit of funk. Light body, dry/tart with a bitter/sour finish. Nice.

Bottle sampled on 9/15/07: Pours a transparent pale golden with a wispy-lacing white head. Aroma of pale biscuity malt and some tart light fruitiness.  Body starts with a fairly-full ginger and pale malty sweetness with decent bready notes and tart, light fruity balance.  Finishes crisp and bittersweet with decent funk and a smooth comlex finish.

Golden, slight haze, huge white head, great lacing. Big sour kick up front. Mostly lemon, with some sour wheat mash. Big yeasty background, hints of oak. Flavor much the same, sour kick up front, fades to grass/barnyard funk through the middle, oak woodiness/dryness in finish. Pretty crisp/refreshing in general. Mouthfeel, seems tad undercarbonated. other than the carbonation this beer has JP written all over it.

Bottle.  Pours a very pale gold color with a pretty substantial head at first that dies quickly and leaves little lacing and a bit of a thin coat of bubbles across the surface.  Aromas are an acrid mix of spices that promises a very tart flavor down the road.  The nose is a little off-putting... In spite of that, the flavor is one of the more palatable that Ive had by Jolly Pumpkin (err... Leelanau).  Pineapple sweetness is a good description of the beginning flavors, and this develops into a bit of a sour transition and then a lemon-grass finish.  All of this with a kind of musty and yeasty backdrop.

MBGF07. Hazy pale body with a small white head. The nose is lightly tart with pineapple, peach, apple cider and bread. The flavor is tart and fairly dry with lemon, lactic acid, pineapple and dough. Medium/light body is soft with moderate carbonation.
Poured a hazy golden color with a medium sized white head.  Leathery funk aroma with yeasty and citrusy notes.  The flavor was lightly tart with a dry finish.  Mild bitterness.
